sections.procedure:
1.  The case originated in an application (no. 32074/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (“the Convention”) by a Romanian national, Ms Luminiţa Zamfira Solcan (“the applicant”), on 17 April 2014.
2.  The applicant was represented by Ms A. Diaconescu, a lawyer practising in Iași. The Romanian Government (“the Government”) were represented by their Agent, most recently Mr. V. Mocanu, of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
3.  The applicant alleged, in particular, a breach of Article 8 of the Convention as a result of the failure of the authorities to allow her to attend her mother’s funeral during her involuntary hospitalisation in an inpatient psychiatric facility.
4.  On 1 September 2015 notice of the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
sections.circumstances:
5.  The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently in a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri.
6.  In 2005 she committed a murder in France. On 12 November 2007 the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on the grounds that she had committed the offence in a state of diminished responsibility. The medical experts diagnosed her as suffering from paranoid schizophrenia and concluded that her acts had been the result of paranoid delusions. Endorsing the experts’ findings that she posed a danger to the public on account of her mental health, the court ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility in France for an indefinite period of time.
7.  In 2011 the applicant lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania in order to be closer to her mother, who lived in Iaşi.
8.  By a decision of 30 March 2012 the Bucharest Court of Appeal authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri, a village located about twenty kilometres from Iaşi. At the time of the latest information available to the Court (9 November 2016), she was still detained there.
9.  On 11 April 2013 the applicant’s mother died. On 12 April 2013 the applicant lodged a request with the Iaşi District Court for leave to attend her funeral.
10.  On 23 May 2013 the court examined her request and refused to grant her leave. It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible. When applying the above provisions to the applicant’s situation, the court held as follows:
“Bearing in mind these legal provisions, the court considers that the safety of others prevails, the patient Solcan Luminiţa having been diagnosed with a mental illness which could potentially present a danger to the lives of others and their feelings of peace and confidence; for this reason, the request made by the patient shall be dismissed ...”
11.  The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision. She claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 on the execution of sentences, which authorised the temporary interruption of a custodial sentence for family reasons, should also apply to her detention in a psychiatric facility. The prosecutor’s office argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility could not be assimilated to a custodial sentence and accordingly there was no legal basis for the interruption of the applicant’s involuntary hospitalisation in a psychiatric facility.
12.  By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal. It held that under Article 114 of the Criminal Code read in conjunction with Article 434 of the Code of Criminal Procedure her detention in a psychiatric facility could be either discontinued or replaced by an obligation to undergo outpatient mental health treatment after an assessment by medical experts. It concluded that the applicant’s request to interrupt her detention in a psychiatric facility had no basis in law and that no analogy could be drawn between her situation and the situation of a prison detainee. Accordingly, the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 authorising the temporary interruption of detention on family grounds were not applicable to her situation. Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid as her mother’s funeral had already taken place.
RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE
13.  The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, as in force at the relevant time, are set out in Filip v. Romania (no. 41124/02, §§ 30-31, 14 December 2006).
14.  Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act (Law no. 487 of 11 July 2002 on mental health and the protection of people with mental disorders) published in Official Gazette no. 589 of 8 August 2002. It was amended by Law no. 600/2004 and subsequently by Law no. 129/2012.
The Mental Health Act does not contain any provisions expressly authorising a judge to interrupt or suspend the involuntary hospitalisation of a mentally ill person.
15.  The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members. In all three case files there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend. After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend their parents’ funerals. Their requests were examined by the court without undue delay so that they could attend. In one of the three cases the request was allowed on the condition that the applicant would be accompanied by medical staff and under police escort.

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 8 October 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: The judgment was finalized.

Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid as her mother’s funeral had already taken place.

events.source_text: RELEVANT DOMESTIC LAW AND PRACTICE 13. The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, as in force at the relevant time, are set out in Filip v. Romania (no. 41124/02, §§ 30-31, 14 December 2006). 14. Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act (Law no. 487 of 11 July 2002 on mental health and the protection of people with mental disorders) published in Official Gazette no. 589 of 8 August 2002. The Mental Health Act does not contain any provisions expressly authorising a judge to interrupt or suspend the involuntary hospitalisation of a mentally ill person.
events.event: governed by the Mental Health Act

events.source_text: 15. The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members. In all three case files there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend. After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend their parents’ funerals. Their requests were examined by the court without undue delay so that they could attend. In one of the three cases the request was allowed on the condition that the applicant would be accompanied by medical staff and under police escort.
events.event_what: allowed attendance at funerals

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, Declares the application admissible; Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; Holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, EUR 6,000 (six thousand euros), to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement, in respect of non-pecuniary damage; that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points; Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: declared application admissible and awarded damages
events.event_what: declared application admissible and awarded damages

events.source_text: On 23 May 2013 the court examined her request and refused to grant her leave. It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible.

It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible.

It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible.

events.source_text: The case originated in an application (no. 32074/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ("the Convention") by a Romanian national, Ms Luminiţa Zamfira Solcan ("the applicant"), on 17 April 2014.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: The applicant was represented by Ms A. Diaconescu, a lawyer practising in Iași.
events.event_what: represented

events.source_text: The Romanian Government ("the Government") were represented by their Agent, most recently Mr. V. Mocanu, of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
events.event: The Romanian Government had legal representation
events.event_what: represented

events.source_text: The applicant alleged, in particular, a breach of Article 8 of the Convention as a result of the failure of the authorities to allow her to attend her mother’s funeral during her involuntary hospitalisation in an inpatient psychiatric facility.
events.event_what: alleged a breach of Article 8

events.source_text: On 1 September 2015 notice of the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 § 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event: The complaint was acknowledged by the government
events.event_what: given notice

events.source_text: The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently in a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri.
events.event: Information about the applicant's current status
events.event_what: born and currently in a psychiatric facility

events.source_text: In 2005 she committed a murder in France.
events.event_what: committed a murder

events.source_text: On 12 November 2007 the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on the grounds that she had committed the offence in a state of diminished responsibility.
events.event_what: discontinued the criminal investigation

events.source_text: The medical experts diagnosed her as suffering from paranoid schizophrenia and concluded that her acts had been the result of paranoid delusions.
events.event: The applicant was diagnosed with a mental disorder
events.event_what: diagnosed as suffering from paranoid schizophrenia

events.source_text: Endorsing the experts’ findings that she posed a danger to the public on account of her mental health, the court ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility in France for an indefinite period of time.
events.event: The applicant was ordered to be hospitalized
events.event_what: ordered her placement in a psychiatric facility

events.source_text: In 2011 the applicant lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania in order to be closer to her mother, who lived in Iaşi.
events.event_what: lodged a request to be transferred

events.source_text: By a decision of 30 March 2012 the Bucharest Court of Appeal authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri, a village located about twenty kilometres from Iaşi.
events.event: The applicant was authorized for transfer
events.event_what: authorized her transfer

events.source_text: On 11 April 2013 the applicant’s mother died.
events.event_what: died

events.source_text: On 12 April 2013 the applicant lodged a request with the Iaşi District Court for leave to attend her funeral.
events.event: The applicant requested permission to attend the funeral
events.event_what: lodged a request with the Iaşi District Court

events.source_text: On 23 May 2013 the court examined her request and refused to grant her leave.
events.event: The court denied the applicant's request
events.event_what: refused to grant her leave

events.source_text: It pointed out that under Article 39 of the Mental Health Act (see paragraph 14 below) the restriction of liberty of mentally ill persons was justified for the protection of their health or safety or for the protection of others, and that under Article 49 of the same Act the facility was chosen so as to allow the mentally ill patient to be as close to home as possible.
events.event: The court provided reasoning for denying the request
events.event_what: pointed out that under Article 39 and 49 of Mental Health Act

events.source_text: When applying the above provisions to the applicant’s situation, the court held as follows:
events.event: The court applied the relevant provisions to the applicant's case
events.event_what: applied the above provisions

events.source_text: “Bearing in mind these legal provisions, the court considers that the safety of others prevails, the patient Solcan Luminiţa having been diagnosed with a mental illness which could potentially present a danger to the lives of others and their feelings of peace and confidence; for this reason, the request made by the patient shall be dismissed ...”
events.event: The court's decision on the applicant's request
events.event_what: considers that the safety of others prevails and dismisses the request

events.source_text: The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision.
events.event_what: lodged an appeal on points of law

events.source_text: She claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 on the execution of sentences, which authorised the temporary interruption of a custodial sentence for family reasons, should also apply to her detention in a psychiatric facility.
events.event: The applicant argued that certain laws should apply to her case
events.event_what: claimed that the provisions of Law no. 275/2006 should apply

events.source_text: The prosecutor’s office argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility could not be assimilated to a custodial sentence and accordingly there was no legal basis for the interruption of the applicant’s involuntary hospitalisation in a psychiatric facility.
events.event: The prosecutor's office provided arguments against the applicant
events.event_what: argued that a measure of detention in a medical facility could not be assimilated to a custodial sentence

events.source_text: By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
events.event_what: dismissed the applicant’s appeal

events.source_text: It held that under Article 114 of the Criminal Code read in conjunction with Article 434 of the Code of Criminal Procedure her detention in a psychiatric facility could be either discontinued or replaced by an obligation to undergo outpatient mental health treatment after an assessment by medical experts.
events.event: The court provided reasoning for dismissing the appeal
events.event_what: held that under Article 114 of Criminal Code and Article 434 of Code of Criminal Procedure

events.source_text: It concluded that the applicant’s request to interrupt her detention in a psychiatric facility had no basis in law and that no analogy could be drawn between her situation and the situation of a prison detainee.
events.event: The court's conclusion on the applicant's request
events.event_what: concluded that the applicant’s request had no basis in law and no analogy could be drawn between her situation and a prison detainee's situation

events.source_text: Moreover, the court noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid as her mother’s funeral had already taken place.
events.event: The court's additional note on the applicant's request
events.event_what: noted that in any event the applicant’s request was no longer valid

events.source_text: The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members.
events.event: The Government provided evidence of similar cases
events.event_what: attached three decisions made by Buzau District Court

events.source_text: In all three case files there was medical evidence proving that they were able to attend.
events.event: Medical evidence was provided for the applicants' ability to attend
events.event_what: provided medical evidence

events.source_text: After assessing the particular circumstances of each applicant, the court granted them leave to attend their parents’ funerals.
events.event: The courts granted leave to attend funerals
events.event_what: granted leave to attend their parents’ funerals

events.source_text: Their requests were examined by the court without undue delay so that they could attend.
events.event_what: examined requests without undue delay

events.source_text: In one of the three cases the request was allowed on the condition that the applicant would be accompanied by medical staff and under police escort.
events.event: One request was granted with conditions
events.event_what: allowed one request on the condition that the applicant would be accompanied by medical staff and under police escort

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY,
events.event: The court made a unanimous decision
events.event_what: made a unanimous decision

events.source_text: Declares the application admissible;
events.event_what: declared the application admissible

events.source_text: Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention;
events.event: The court found a violation of Article 8
events.event_what: holds that there has been a violation of Article 8

events.source_text: Holds that the respondent State is to pay the applicant, within three months from the date on which the judgment becomes final in accordance with Article 44 § 2 of the Convention, EUR 6,000 (six thousand euros), to be converted into the currency of the respondent State at the rate applicable at the date of settlement, in respect of non-pecuniary damage;
events.event: The court ordered compensation for non-pecuniary damages
events.event_what: ordered compensation for non-pecuniary damage

events.source_text: that from the expiry of the above-mentioned three months until settlement simple interest shall be payable on the above amount at a rate equal to the marginal lending rate of the European Central Bank during the default period plus three percentage points;
events.event: The court ordered interest on the compensation
events.event_what: ordered interest on the compensation

events.source_text: Dismisses the remainder of the applicant’s claim for just satisfaction.
events.event: The court dismissed the rest of the applicant's claim
events.event_what: dismissed the remainder of the applicant’s claim

events.source_text: Done in English, and notified in writing on 8 October 2019, pursuant to Rule 77 §§ 2 and 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: done in English, notified in writing

events.event_what: lodged an application

events.event_what: authorised her transfer

events.event_what: committed a murder

events.source_text: On 12 November 2007 the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on the grounds that she had committed the offence in a state of diminished responsibility.
events.event_what: discontinued an investigation

events.source_text: In 2011 the applicant lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania in order to be closer to her mother, who lived in Iaşi.

events.source_text: On 9 November 2016, she was still detained there.
events.event_what: detained

events.source_text: By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iaşi County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.

events.source_text: The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members.
events.event_what: allowed applicants to attend a funeral

events.source_text: FOR THESE REASONS, THE COURT, UNANIMOUSLY, Declares the application admissible; Holds that there has been a violation of Article 8 of the Convention; Holds ...

events.source_text: 1. The case originated in an application (no. 32074/14) against Romania lodged with the Court under Article 34 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms ('the Convention') by a Romanian national, Ms Luminița Zamfira Solcan ('the applicant'), on 17 April 2014.
events.event_what: lodged an application

events.source_text: 2. The applicant was represented by Ms A. Diaconescu, a lawyer practising in Iași. The Romanian Government ('the Government') were represented by their Agent, most recently Mr. V. Mocanu, of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
events.event_what: represented

events.source_text: 3. The applicant alleged, in particular, a breach of Article 8 of the Convention as a result of the failure of the authorities to allow her to attend her mother’s funeral during her involuntary hospitalisation in an inpatient psychiatric facility.
events.event_what: alleged breach of Article 8

events.source_text: 4. On 1 September 2015 notice of the complaint under Article 8 of the Convention was given to the Government and the remainder of the application was declared inadmissible pursuant to Rule 54 Ó 3 of the Rules of Court.
events.event_what: notice of complaint given, remainder of application declared inadmissible

events.source_text: 5. The applicant was born in 1969 and is currently in a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri.
events.event_what: applicant's current situation

events.source_text: 6. In 2005 she committed a murder in France. On 12 November 2007 the Mâcon County Court discontinued the criminal investigation against her on the grounds that she had committed the offence in a state of diminished responsibility.
events.event_what: criminal investigation discontinued

events.source_text: 7. In 2011 the applicant lodged a request to be transferred to a similar psychiatric facility in Romania in order to be closer to her mother, who lived in Iași.
events.event_what: lodged a transfer request

events.source_text: 8. By a decision of 30 March 2012 the Bucharest Court of Appeal authorised her transfer to a psychiatric facility in Pădureni-Grajduri, a village located about twenty kilometres from Iași.
events.event_what: transfer authorised

events.source_text: 9. On 11 April 2013 the applicant’s mother died. On 12 April 2013 the applicant lodged a request with the Iași District Court for leave to attend her funeral.
events.event_what: lodged a request to attend mother's funeral

events.source_text: 10. On 23 May 2013 the court examined her request and refused to grant her leave.
events.event_what: court examined request and refused leave

events.source_text: 11. The applicant lodged an appeal on points of law against that decision.
events.event_what: lodged an appeal

events.source_text: 12. By a final decision of 22 October 2013 the Iași County Court dismissed the applicant’s appeal.
events.event_what: applicant's appeal dismissed

events.source_text: 13. The relevant provisions of the Criminal Code and the Code of Criminal Procedure, as in force at the relevant time, are set out in Filip v. Romania (no. 41124/02, §§ 30-31, 14 December 2006).
events.event_what: relevant provisions of Criminal Code and Code of Criminal Procedure

events.source_text: 14. Psychiatric detention is governed by the provisions of the Mental Health Act (Law no. 487 of 11 July 2002 on mental health and the protection of people with mental disorders) published in Official Gazette no. 589 of 8 August 2002.
events.event_what: psychiatric detention governed by Mental Health Act

events.source_text: 15. The Government attached to their observations three decisions made by the Buzau District Court (on 30 January 2014, 6 February and 27 March 2015 respectively) by which the applicants, who had all been admitted to a psychiatric facility for inpatient treatment, were allowed to attend the funerals of their family members.
events.event_what: applicants allowed to attend funerals
